title: Orbiting satellites - 2 asteroids orbiting a star

content.question: Two small asteroids, Asteroid <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> and Asteroid <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, are in elliptical orbits about the same star, as shown in the figure. The asteroids interact gravitationally with the star, but exert negligible gravitational forces on each other. Points <math alttext="P " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi></math> and <math alttext="Q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Q</mi></math> are where asteroids <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> and <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, respectively, are the closest to the star, and Asteroid <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> is passing through Point <math alttext="P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi></math> at the same instant that Asteroid <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> is passing through Point <math alttext="Q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Q</mi></math>. Which of the following claims about the asteroids-star system’s total angular momentum <math alttext="L sub system" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>L</mi><mtext>sys</mtext></msub></math> about the star is correct, and what evidence supports the claim?

choices.label: <math alttext="L sub system" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>L</mi><mtext>sys</mtext></msub></math> remains constant. The acceleration of each asteroid is independent of its mass.

<math alttext="L sub system" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>L</mi><mtext>sys</mtext></msub></math> remains constant. The gravitational force on each asteroid does not result in a torque about the star.

<math alttext="L sub system" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>L</mi><mtext>sys</mtext></msub></math> has a maximum magnitude when the asteroids are at points <math alttext="P " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi></math> and <math alttext="Q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Q</mi></math>. These are the locations where the asteroids’ speeds are greatest.

<math alttext="L sub system" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>L</mi><mtext>sys</mtext></msub></math> has a maximum magnitude when the asteroids are at points <math alttext="P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi></math> and <math alttext="Q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Q</mi></math>. These locations are where the asteroids are the closest to the star.

content.answer: <math alttext="L sub system" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>L</mi><mtext>sys</mtext></msub></math> remains constant. The gravitational force on each asteroid does not result in a torque about the star.
